If your grew up in the 90s and you had a decent computer, chances are you had played or at least heard of a game called The Incredible Machine. It was a game that asked you to, for example, toast some breads using bombs, lasers, switches, conveyor belts, etc, in a Rube Goldberg style. The idea was novel and the game contributed to hours and hours of fun, even though I was too young to understand much of it.

Then few years later, another similar game called The Incredible Toon Machine came out, which from what I remember, added a few animals like Al the cat and Sid the mouse. It was not officially part of the series; everything looked more cartoonish, but I still spent even more hours blowing stuff up. I was older (therefore wiser), and it was still in the 90s.

Toon Machine was the last game in the series I played. Fans like me have waited many, many years for a remake of this classic game. Imagine my joy when I saw Contraption Maker on Steam, made by none other than the creators of the original TIM.

The game itself has over 100 official puzzles, not to mention the plethora of user-made puzzles on Steam Workshop. The developer continues to update the game with new stuff, and the puzzles are challenging. They may seem easy in the beginning, but as you go through them, especially in the medium and hard section, you may find yourself pulling your hair when you cannot toast those breads after 20 tries.

In short,

* if you had played The Incredible Machine and loved it, you will very easily love Contraption Maker.
* if you (god forbid) had not played or heard of TIM before, but for some reason you like toasting breads with bombs and lasers, you will very easily love Contraption Maker.
* if you had not played or heard of TIM before, and don't like Rube Goldberg machine, then I regret to tell you that you are missing out the fun and want to thank you for reading my review anyway.[/list]

As an extra motivation, you will get two copies when you buy now. Give it to your buddy and let them toast some breads!

reviewText:
The original creators of The Incredible Machine have returned to bring a childhood favorite back from the dead. SO MUCH YES.

The Incredible Machine is a physics puzzle game. It's not just just any physics puzzle game, though; it was the first! Before Scribblenauts, before World of Goo, before Garry's Mod, even before all those crazy flash games on Newgrounds, it was The Incredible Machine that let gamers discover the joy of physics sandbox chaos. Many hours of fun were had feeding tiny children to alligators and dropping huge piles of cats onto trampolines. The puzzles themselves were sublime, teaching foresight and out-of-the-box thinking in ways that were unheard of at the time. I'd go so far as to say that The Incredible Machine 3 is probably my top pick for best puzzle game of all time.

There have been clones and copycats over the years with varying levels of quality (Bad Rats, anyone?), but now you don't have to settle for imitations! This is the same game as it was 20 years ago, only with a new name and a fresh coat of HD paint it so greatly deserved. All the old machine parts are back, puzzle size and complexity is UNLIMITED, and Steam Workshop integration means that the world can see the puzzles you make (rather than just whatever friends or family you could trick into playing your custom puzzle). The music is almost as good as the old soundtracks, and just try not to shed a tear of nostalgia when you clear a puzzle and hear whew!"

The interface still has some annoying kinks to work out

reviewText:
Finally a successor to the The Incredible Machine (TIM) series! If you played TIM, buy this! If you like puzzles, buy this! If you like throwing cats with deadpan faces off the screen, buy this! Even without going on sale, the game has quite a bit of content you don't have to worry about not getting your money's worth, unless you're not into this type of game at all. I got this for the equivalent of 0.50 USD during Summer Sale 2015. That is such a freaking steal that I am now a professional thief.

Mechanics:
There are many new parts that were added in this game. Just to name a few, you now have Tinker the dog, as well as many variations of Tim (Sledding? Walking? Snowball-throwing?). The variations in Tim, in particular, makes sense as Tim used to just be the cannon fodder that you threw everywhere with boxing gloves, springs, anti-gravity pads, as well as getting him stuck on a blimp, all with the aim of getting him back to his house. This increases the number of ways you can throw cats with deadpan faces off the screen.

Many parts can now be adjusted to have their area of effect changed. For example, the scissors used to be something that can only be placed horizontally, but now it can be rotated 360 degrees. You can also choose at what angle you wish the kettle to blow an object. All these improvements combine to make the game deeper and more flexible.

You also no longer have to struggle with placement of objects. There were some puzzles where you had to adjust your objects by the pixel so that they would get contact in the exact right spot and respond to each other. That's no longer the case here. The hitbox is bigger now, which does not make the game easier, though it does make it much less frustrating. You no longer have to worry about the stupid candle not being in the exact right spot to launch the rocket.

Also on the topic of mechanics, the addition of a fast-forward button is simply genius. There have been many times in TIM where puzzles take more than 15-30 seconds to execute in its entirety. Combined with the earlier-mentioned problem of object detection, it can be extremely annoying. This solves that problem, and can also save you time if you're a veteran player wishing to blow past the easy levels.

Art and Sound:
This may just be the nostalgia speaking, but The Incredible Machine series had a very engaging soundtrack, whether it was the MIDI or the upgraded non-MIDI version. CM's do not stand out particularly as very good compositions, and there are a few pieces of music that are slightly grating (like the main theme). Having said that, I must qualify that CM's soundtrack is actually decent, just not as good as TIM's.

Next, the art style of CM is very different from TIM. While TIM goes for a clean and flat look (likely an artifact of the technological restrictions at the time), CM has a more shaded" style of art which is very obvious on certain objects like Tinker the dog. I slightly prefer TIM's art style

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Whether you like the great feeling of solving seemingly complex Rube-Goldberg puzzles or simply having a physics sandbox (of sorts) to play with, Contraption Maker is a delightful addition to anyone's Steam Library. Even in its Alpha state, the game already has tons of building parts, many of them from the legacy The Incredible Machine series (also developed by the awesome team that made this!), and a few new ones, too.

Some parts are still lacking proper art, but that's not something you should worry about - Contraption Maker is still in development, and many things in game can't be considered 'final'. Moreover, I think the developers have stated that skinning support will be available at some point in the future. Anyway, it is at gameplay that this title really excels! Playing with explosives, blimps and even alligators is completely safe here, not to mention plenty of fun. :)

The new Alpha releases have brought a significant amount of content to the game, since the first one. New parts, bug fixes, some amazing pieces of soundtrack (which is great, as the original The Incredible Machine had excellent tunes) and even a working multiplayer mode! I see lots of potential here.

All in all, would I recommend this game? Heck, yes! This is the kind of game I'd want my own kids to enjoy.
Well, maybe if you really HATE puzzles and Rube-Goldberg machines you should stay away from this. Otherwise, do try Contraption Maker, it will be worth every penny you spend on it.

Whereas the Crazy Machines series (good in its own right) is best thought of as a reimagining of the classic The Incredible Machine series, Contraption Maker is a straight-up reboot of TIM.  Nearly everything from TIM2 (or 3.0, etc) is there, featuring an interface that'll be second nature to any old veterans of the game.  It also adds in a few new parts here and there that take better advantage of a more robust physics engine and some graphical and design improvements you'd expect for a modern version of an older game.

Definitely worthwhile for any fan of the TIM series.  And even in its current unfinished state, well worth a look for anyone who wants to have fun designing virtual Rube Goldberg machines.

Being familiar with The Incredible Machine, I picked this up to reminisce and have some fun with puzzles. Besides, a two for one!? That's great.

For me the puzzles didn't get challenging until hard difficulty. Perhaps I was younger, however, I remember The Incredible Machine puzzles being much harder. Therefore, the previous difficulties seemed to just take time to put the pieces in place.

Play time included about 8-9 hours for me to finish all the official puzzles. Played some of the Editor's Choice community mods and puzzles. There certainly is much more content if you factor in the community puzzles. However, one challenge is that the game fails to keep a progress of what community puzzles you've solved--unlike the official puzzles.

With all that said, it's a great game, and I recommend it. Perhaps a 8/10. Support the developers if you'd like to see more of these types of options.

Certainly have some fond memories of The Incredible Machine, so I'm pleased to see this released!

reviewText:
Long ago, when I was but a wee lad, I played a game called The Incredible Machine as part of my schooling. Hours of my tutelage in the basement computer lab of my school were spent in blissful abandon playing that wonder of a game, comparing my elaborate constructions to my equally-enthralled pubescent minds, We were gods of all creation, and in our experimentation bonds of eternal friendship were erected alongside the craziest, most Goldbergian of useless designs. It was a fire of friendship that flared, roared, and fizzled away as we slowly grew apart.

Now, in my twenties, apart from those pre-pubescent paragons of pointless perfection, the fire has been rekindled. This game is whimsical and childish enough to make you remember those happier childhood days without pandering to you. I experienced some minor technical difficulties (including a persistent drone on the title screen), but nothing to make the game unplayable.

It's a lot of nostalgic fun. Get it when it comes on sale.

The puzzles here, however, seem less thought out than TIM puzzles, and many of the levels (including hard levels) were easily beaten by exploiting the set up thus making the objective trivial to accomplish. One I do miss was the monkey on the bike where you pull the shade down revealing a banana then it would start pedaling, which is similar to one of the new items in this game, but without the ability to cancel the pedaling by impact i.e. dropping a cannonball on the monkey's head.

tl;dr
I bought this game for $1.50 and it came with 2 copies.
Puzzles were enjoyable but not very challenging.
Replayability relies on the community as far as I can tell.

7/10 (+2 Price, +2 Enjoyable, +1 Nostalgia, +1 Removed the pointless score system TIM had, +1 Ability to share puzzles with community)

Hey! Perhaps you're looking for some nice well written review! Well here I am!
First off, I made a video review specifically for this game so feel free to check it out :)
http://youtu.be/xyCdD2nWxM8
**The written version:**

I have to say that since the moment I discovered there is a remake of Incredible Machine being made by the same peeps that made it way back I was excited like a little baby and also cautious, because we all know how the remakes/sequels/etc. go right!?

I fired this game up, a beautiful bright colourful menu with awesome music greeted me. Well this is starting great. I had little to no read about this game, haven't prepared and I just went for it as it was in my library. I fired up the tutorial sessions, and oh boy.. nostalgia punched me right in my face.

I did finish the tutorial level in about 30 minutes, not letting my eyes go off the screen for a brief moment. This game is just addictive and plain fun. It's like 2D Gmod with awesome stuff like lasers, cannons, cheese, and much more. You didn't play the original Incredible Machine? Well no worries, you don't really have to! This game is great on its own (and even better if you know the original). The redesigned graphics are awesome and well fitting (apart from the cat animation that seemed weird to me), the music is creative, funny, positive and evoking a sense of playfulness. Everything is .. great!

But thats not all. Its not just a polished refurbished Incredible Machine. THIS THING HAS WORKSHOP! You can create contraptions and puzzles for other people to play, and there's already over a 1000!!! That's something absolutely great and adds up so much more to this game and genre! This is something that was not possible during the time Incredible Machine was released and its just AWESOME.

And that's not all! There's multiplayer! YOU CAN BUILD STUFF WITH UP TO 7 FRIENDS! Holy cow. I haven't had the chance to try the multiplayer out yet, because my friends don't own this yet (I will make them), but oh boy thats something I'm so much looking forward too.

Are you looking for a game that can bend by your logic and creativity? Do you wanna create fun machines that act complicated but do silly stuff? Do you wanna laugh? Want a game for the whole family? Want something that you fire up at any time and you have something to do every time? WELL THEN THIS GAME IS FOR YOU! (And that's not even the whole list of questions!)

Pros
+ Cute graphics
+ Cute physics
+ Workshop!
+ Multiplayer :3
+ Funny!
+ Great music.
+ LOT OF CONTENT
+ Friendly and dedicated developers!!!!!!! (One of the VERY FEW successful early access games!)
+ Nostalgia all the way! (if you played the original)
+ For any age.

Cons
- Addictive (OH GOD IS THAT A CON?! Nah)

reviewText:
Contraption Maker really met my expectation - definitely worth the purchase especially I get an extra copy to share to friends.

Quick facts for those too lazy to read on:

+ TIM's successor with upgraded engine and physic
+ Lots of new stuff to play with (parts, scenery...)
+ Make mode for custom puzzle creation
+ Steam Workshop (Share your own / play community's puzzles)
+ 2-key pack (Great for gifting friends / do giveaway event)
+ New content still coming everyone once in a while

- Not working properly on small screen (Laptop users may find this bothersome)
- Drag 'n drop replaced Click 'n drop, needs time to get used to

Now it's full review (WARNING: Wall of text up ahead!)

For those who are new to the party, Contraption Maker is your Rube Goldberg puzzle games - you are given some parts to fill up in the contraption to achieve specific goal(s), and it's up to you to work out how they connect with each other. Tutorial levels are a good start to get to know all the parts, and the puzzles get harder and harder (and trickier) as you play through Easy, Normal and Hard. The best part of CM, just like original T.I.M, is that you can create your own puzzle / contraption, and with Steam Workshop, you can even publish them for other players to play. Community work will definitely keep this game long live even if the developers stop updating. One more thing, unofficially, you are even allowed to texture/sound mod CM to your heart's content (Though, part's physical won't change, just their appearance). I've heard that the developers intend to make it Steam Workshop friendly in the future, so custom skins are another new thing we could expect.

Contraption Maker hasn't changed much comparing to The Incredible Machine - if you love T.I.M, you will love CM as well because they are quite similar, and CM is made even better with new parts, physics and interface, something you definitely can't find with $15 for 2 copies pack. Of course there are some changes and tweak there and now (Such as you now have to drag 'n' drop parts and click on them to see additional options), but I guess we can get used to it in no time.

Given that CM has just left Early access, there are still some problems with minority user bases (me included, which is why I will state here). This game will not work properly on small monitor (Under 1280 x 720), so if you are using ancient LCD like me now, wait till you get a bigger one first. As mentioned, the change from drag 'n' drop parts and click on them for additional options can be a little annoying when building contraption / puzzle - if you won't zoom in, you may not be able to select the part you want to as the game just lock to whatever part near it instead. Finally, there are still some issue publishing contraption / puzzle to Workshop - unfortunately, a single Failed" messenger won't help you much

reviewText:
The spiritual sucessor to The Incredible Machine, with the same quirky humor and sometimes ludecrous solutions, is here in the form of Contraption Maker.

The game revolves around you assembling Rube Goldberg machines to perform otherwise trivial tasks, like activating a can opener, or guiding a mouse back home.  This gameplay requires you to think outside the box for a majority of the puzzles, which makes solving them all the more satisfying.  Anyone can pick up this game.

The sound design is amazing, from the music to the sound effects.  A lot of love was put into keeping the atmosphere as similar to The Incredible Machine as copyright would allow.  Everything sounds exactly the way it should.

In my opinion, the game's best feature is the Steam Workshop compatibility.  With it, you can share machines you've made with everyone who owns the game, so even if you complete all the built-in levels, you can still enjoy the game.

With all of this said, I love this game (My playtime is deceving).  It's fun, and well crafted, taking everything I loved from The Incredible Machine and improving it.

This game gets my Seal of Recomendation.  It is a must-have title.  If it looks like fun to you, odds are, it will be.  Pick it up, even at full price.  Not to mention, you get two copies for less than average price.  Put your thinking caps on.

You'll Enjoy This Game If You Like:                Logic                The Incredible Machine                    Over complicated solutions to easy tasks                 Physics Puzzles                 Level editors/customisation
If you've ever wanted to mess around with Rube Goldberg machines, then this is your chance! The premise of the game is to create riduculous, complex machines to achieve a simple task. Your machines will have knock on effects - a ball rolls along a conveyor belt, which knocks into scissors which cut a rope which drops a bucket and so on.

The puzzles get very difficult as you go through, so you will need somewhat of a logical mind to figure them out. The real fun for me comes in the level editor where you are able to create your very own Rube Goldberg machines rather than just place a few items in to complete an existing machine in the main game.

If you love puzzles and don't get easily frustrated then grab this game now!

reviewText:
The charm of Contraption Maker is that, like The Incredible Machine before it, it provides a fairly self-explanatory framework in which to create and solve a variety of puzzles, ranging from the mundane (pop a balloon) to the esoteric (fire a series of lasers in order to make breakfast, clean the house, and feed the dog and cat and mouse and crocodile and bear). It's good, clean fun for everyone that also challenges you to flex your mental muscles as well, both on developer-made as well as community-made puzzles.

Some people will make claims that the game limits you by only giving one way to solve a given puzzle. Hardly the case, if you ask me. I solved more than a few puzzles with thinking so far out of the box that the official solution bore not the slightest resemblance what I ended up doing, and the puzzle still had the good grace to acknowledge my solution as valid because I accomplished the objective it demanded with the parts it provided, even if I didn't use them remotely like they were intended. This is clearly not a 'one answer and only one answer' game.

Does it have flaws? A few. The plug system takes a little getting used to (since the game now rather aggressively plugs in parts for you), and a handful of parts are a touch too loose in definition--the free rotation of smaller parts or walls isn't bad, but it can be a bit of a chore to line up some parts just right without relying on the snap-to function built into the game. I also miss the old music from the old The Incredible Machine days, but that's just auditory nostalgia on my part.

All in all though, a lot of fun for thinky folks. A cute little game that brings back good old memories while remaining accessible and affordable in spite of a few minor hiccups.

reviewText:
It's pretty enjoyable even for people who don't generally like puzzle games.  There are a staggering amount of official puzzles (I'm nowhere near finishing them all) of varying difficulties, and most of the ones I've played are great.  There are also a ton of community-made puzzles.  Some of them are really good, and some are terrible but funny in their terribleness.

The most fun part for me was the level editor.  You can make your own contraptions and puzzles using all the parts in the game.  The editor is a little awkward, but generally easy to use.

Most annoying part of the game is the bad UI.  The actual game mechanics are really well-done, so I have no clue why they failed so badly with the UI. Exiting a puzzle should take you back to the page number where you found the puzzle, not the main puzzle page.  There should also be an in-game way to search through the puzzles by name or author, how does this not exist?  These are really basic features- it makes you wonder if they actually tested anything outside of the puzzles/contraptions.

But it's still a really fun game, or else I'd never put up with the other stuff.  It's very satisfying to create a convoluted contraption all just to accomplish the simple task of, say, turning on a blender.

reviewText:
The original The Incredible Machine was one of my favorite games when I was a kid. TIM3 was the high point of the series, but to me the Return of the Incredible Machine: Contraptions was a big let-down and a huge step back. Also, having tried some other remakes of my old favorites, like some of the new Worms games, I was more than a bit sceptical on how this game would turn out.

Luckily I was worried for nothing! I find the new TIM.. I mean, Contraption Maker, every bit as good as its best predecessor. The easy puzzles are, of course, really easy, and there's a lot of them, but you can skip to the more difficult puzzles whenever you want for the added satisfaction of solving them. You can also pick any one from the pre-made 200-300 puzzles, so you won't get stuck without being able to continue.

There's also, of course, the free building mode, where you can create your own contraptions and puzzles, and share them via Steam Workshop, which is nicely built into the game. There's a good amount of parts and people have been constructing some pretty great things. What's more, there's even support for modding.

Warmly recommended for anyone into puzzle or building games.

I've only played this for a brief while, but as a fan of the Incredible Machine franchise, I'd say this is a worthy successor for the most part. If I had to nitpick, I'd say that the art style is rather off-putting and at times it even confuses me, to the point where I can't tell what I'm looking at (which is horrible, because the original games were designed so that you could understand what most of the objects did by looking at them). Secondly, while I don't necessarily think the original games had amazing music, the music they have here is rather bland at best, to annoying at worst.

But obviously I wouldn't be giving this a thumbs up if I didn't think it was worth it. Compared to all the contemporaries that have cropped up in recent years, Contraption Maker is a wonderful return to form for a series that has long been neglected. The game mechanics are good, the interface takes a bit of getting used to for a TIM veteran but I've grown to like it.

If there was a way to create custom assets and different music libraries for this game, I would be glad, because virtually everything besides the underlying mechanics sort've lets this whole package down in a way. Not enough for me to hate it, per se, but I think the difference here is that I can play the old TIM games for hours on end, whereas this game I need to pause every now and then and wash my eyes.

If you ever played The Incredible Machine on Windows 95 or 98 (TIM for short), then you will already know what this game is like.  TIM was essentially a kids game with some cool kinetic trap making that allowed for adults to have fun playing it too.

Contraption Maker was fun.  I have two downsides that are pretty much entirely subjective.  First, the graphics are bright and cheery.  That would seem like a positive for some, but for me it's like looking at a rainbow that is moving.  It gets slightly irritating after awhile.  Secondly, I felt as though the game attempted to be more on the funny side rather than the serious side.

I don't know who their target audiece was, and I felt that the game might be too complex for kids, and too childish for adults.

With all that being said, I would ultimately recommend this game.  It is fun.  I put sunglasses on for the colors, and I am happy that such a game still exists.  Maybe a few kids will latch onto it, and maybe a few adults will relive nostalgia.

reviewText:
This really is like the old Incredible Machines games, even down to the selection of parts in many of the puzzles. It follows the same logic (or arguably lack thereof in some cases), and does encourage you to draw on knowledge from various areas, such as mixing primary colours. This allows it to work well for both adults and children alike, and I suspect its target is children supervised by parents for help with the harder puzzles. And trust me, there are ones even adults will likely have a head-scratch over (I know I have at times!).

My only real gripes are that the controls are a little iffy, particularly with placing parts. The menus around items are not context-sensitive so it can get frustrating when placing items in certain areas, as you can't access the menus properly - you have to rotate somewhere else before putting the part in, as an example - which means some puzzles require more clicks than they need simply because there's no allowance made for menus going off the screen. The game also does seem to hold your hand a little too long, with many of the first puzzles (even past the first 50) being a case of 'clone/mirror the other half of the screen' or 'fill the obvious blank', so it can get a little tiresome early on.

But do continue. It's good.
